articles.headline: 18 Orgies Later, Chinese Swinger Gets Prison Bed
articles.snippet: Ma Yaohai, who used online chat rooms to arrange group sex encounters, was sentenced to prison for “crowd licentiousness.”
articles.abstract: Ma Yaohai, who used online chat rooms to arrange group sex encounters, was sentenced to prison for “crowd licentiousness.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In public, he was a twice-divorced computer science professor dedicated to his students and to caring for an elderly mother who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease.

articles.headline: Calling on Sony and Others, Google Makes a TV Move
articles.snippet: Google TV promises to integrate the Web and TV, but it relies on TV manufacturers to use its software.
articles.abstract: Google TV promises to integrate the Web and TV, but it relies on TV manufacturers to use its software.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google recruited a solid lineup of high-tech companies on Thursday to help it introduce Google TV, a new service that merges the predictable world of television programming with the more chaotic expanse of the Web.

articles.headline: Bill Passed in Senate Broadly Expands Oversight of Wall St.
articles.snippet: The Senate vote on Thursday puts Congress on the brink of approving a far-reaching financial regulatory bill.
articles.abstract: The Senate vote on Thursday puts Congress on the brink of approving a far-reaching financial regulatory bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday approved a far-reaching financial regulatory bill, putting Congress on the brink of approving a broad expansion of government oversight of the increasingly complex banking system and financial markets.

articles.headline: Padded Pensions Add to New York Fiscal Woes
articles.snippet: Errors, misunderstandings and wishful thinking are piling hidden costs onto New York’s pension system.
articles.abstract: Errors, misunderstandings and wishful thinking are piling hidden costs onto New York’s pension system.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Yonkers, more than 100 retired police officers and firefighters are collecting pensions greater than their pay when they were working. One of the youngest, Hugo Tassone, retired at 44 with a base pay of about $74,000 a year. His pension is now $101,333 a year.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Amy Schoenfeld

articles.headline: Tea Party Pick Causes Uproar on Civil Rights
articles.snippet: Rand Paul, the Republican nominee for the Senate in Kentucky, suggested that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 was too broad.
articles.abstract: Rand Paul, the Republican nominee for the Senate in Kentucky, suggested that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 was too broad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rand Paul, the Tea Party candidate who challenged the Republican establishment to win the party’s Senate nomination in Kentucky two days ago, criticized a landmark civil rights law on Thursday, landing himself in a potentially damaging dispute over civil rights and race.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Trichet Faces Growing Criticism in Europe Crisis
articles.snippet: As the European Central Bank has struggled to contain Europe’s debt crisis, Mr. Trichet has given ground on some principles and opened himself to criticism.
articles.abstract: As the European Central Bank has struggled to contain Europe’s debt crisis, Mr. Trichet has given ground on some principles and opened himself to criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — For the first time in a long life of technocratic excellence, the president of the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, finds both his judgment and his credibility in question.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Naked Truth on Default Swaps
articles.snippet: The argument raging over credit-default swaps would not be taking place if regulators had done their jobs years ago and classified them as insurance.
articles.abstract: The argument raging over credit-default swaps would not be taking place if regulators had done their jobs years ago and classified them as insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should people be able to bet on your death? How about your financial failure?

articles.headline: Many Hopes Ride on Makeover of the Grand Cherokee
articles.snippet: The redesigned Jeep Grand Cherokee, a crossover vehicle with a $31,000 price tag, is being lauded by the troubled automaker as the “symbol of the new Chrysler.”
articles.abstract: The redesigned Jeep Grand Cherokee, a crossover vehicle with a $31,000 price tag, is being lauded by the troubled automaker as the “symbol of the new Chrysler.”
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — During the last two weeks at a large assembly plant here, the first glimpse into Chrysler’s future has been zipping through production.

articles.headline: Facing a Rift, U.S. Spy Chief to Step Down
articles.snippet: Adm. Dennis C. Blair often clashed with the White House while director of national intelligence.
articles.abstract: Adm. Dennis C. Blair often clashed with the White House while director of national intelligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dennis C. Blair, whose often tumultuous tenure as director of national intelligence was marked by frequent clashes with White House officials and other spy chiefs in America’s still fractured intelligence apparatus, announced Thursday that he was resigning.

articles.headline: How the Finance Bill Affects Consumers
articles.snippet: The Senate’s version of the overhaul bill could result in more discounts to people who pay in cash.
articles.abstract: The Senate’s version of the overhaul bill could result in more discounts to people who pay in cash.
articles.lead_paragraph: For consumers trying to figure out what the financial overhaul bill means for them, the legislation the Senate passed Thursday offers some tantalizing possibilities.
